metadata.case_name: State of Assam v. Mool Chand Sarougi

facts.text: The Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division, Assam invited tenders for the purchase of monopoly rights to quarry stone from certain areas, including Harengi Stone Quarry Mahal, for the period July 1, 1963 to June 30, 1964.
Mool Chand Sarougi (respondent) submitted a tender accompanied by the requisite deposit of Rs. 100/- as earnest money, and offered the rate of Rs. 5.25 per rupee of royalty.

The tender submitted by the respondent was accepted and for the minimum quantity of 1,25,000 c. ft. of stone allotted to the respondent out of the quarry he was to pay Rs. 31,250/-. Intimation of acceptance of the tender was given to the respondent on July 13, 1963.
One Baputi Ram, a member of a scheduled tribe, appealed against the order of the Divisional Forest Officer accepting the tender, to the Government of Assam and obtained a stay order.
After about three months Baputi Ram declined to prosecute the appeal and his appeal was dismissed.
The respondent then declined to accept the settlement of the quarry.
The Divisional Forest Officer invited fresh tenders. The offers made were lower however accepted and tenders were invited again.
On January 10, 1964 a settlement was made for a minimum quantity of 50,000 c. ft. for the period from January 25, 1964 to June 30, 1964 for Rs. 10,000/-

The Divisional Forest Officer sought to recover the amount of Rs. 31,250/- for which the tender of the respondent was accepted as arrears of land revenue in the manner provided by S. 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891.
The respondent moved a petition in the High Court of Assam for an order quashing the proceeding for recovery of the amount demanded.

The High Court held that the amount claimed was not recoverable under the provisions of the Assam Forest Regulation, VII of 1891 and passed an order quashing the proceeding for recovery and issued a mandamus to the Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division not to proceed with the recovery.

The State of Assam appealed to this Court with certificate granted by the High Court. Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1966, of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 242 of 1964.

legal_issues.text: Whether the amount of Rs. 31,250/- claimed from the respondent is recoverable under Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891 as arrears of land revenue, including whether it is due under rule 10 promulgated under the Regulation.
Whether stone is forest produce within the meaning of the Assam Forest Regulation.

petitioner_arguments.text: The amount was due under rule 10 promulgated in exercise of power under the Regulation and on that account it was recoverable as an arrear of land revenue.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 10 of Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891; Section 75 of Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891

respondent_arguments.text: The amount claimed was not recoverable under the provisions of the Assam Forest Regulation, VII of 1891.

court_reasoning.text: The amount claimed to be due from the respondent is not on account of the price of any forest produce, or of expenses incurred in the execution for recovery of any forest produce. The amount is also not due in the execution of the Regulation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: So far there is common ground.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 10 provides No lease for any fixed period giving the right of removing India rubber, cane, kutcha or cutch, lac, agar, ivory, or any other forests produce shall be given otherwise than in accordance with the general or special orders of the Conservator who is empowered to authorise sales in respect of such leases, by auction, tender or any other method at such rates as he may decide in his discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The Rule does not apply to recovery of the amount alleged to be due for failure to carry out the obligations of the tender by proceedings under the Assam Forest Regulation 1891.

court_reasoning.text: It is again difficult to hold that stone is forest produce within the meaning of the Act.

In any event the Rule does not give rise to any liability to pay a sum of money. It merely imposes a limitation upon the power of the officers of the Forest Department to grant leases in respect of certain forest produce.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is a rule relating to the exercise of power to grant leases.

court_reasoning.text: The amount of damages for breach of the terms of the sale notice is not an amount due under the Regulation, or rule 10 made thereunder.

holdings.text: The amount claimed is not recoverable under Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891 as arrears of land revenue.
Rule 10 does not apply to recovery for failure to carry out tender obligations and does not create monetary liability.
Stone is not forest produce within the meaning of the Act.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 75 provides for recovery of moneys payable under the Regulation as arrears of land revenue; court held amount not recoverable thereunder. Rule 10 regulates granting of leases for forest produce and does not create liability for tender failure.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's order quashing the proceedings for recovery of Rs. 31,250/- from the respondent as arrears of land revenue under Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891, holding that the amount is not due under the Regulation or Rule 10, and stone is not forest produce.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order quashing recovery proceedings and mandamus not to proceed with recovery upheld.

key_quotes.text: The High Court was, in our judgment, right in observing that the amount of damages for breach of the terms of the sale notice is not an amount due under the Regulation, or rule 10 made thereunder.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding dismissing the appeal and affirming High Court.

key_quotes.text: It is again difficult to hold that stone is forest produce within the meaning of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key observation on scope of 'forest produce' under the Regulation.
